A public health model is required to deal with knife crime – lives depend on it  The Independent

item.description:
Theresa May faces prospect of more resignations after Andrea Leadsom rejects key part of Brexit plan  The Independent

A second cabinet minister has rejected a key plank of Theresa May’s Brexit plan, raising the prospect of fresh resignations if she tries to force it through. Andrea Leadsom, the Commons leader also warned the proposal – giving the EU a joint say over when the UK can break free of the Irish border “backstop” – would be thrown out by parliament. item.title: Theresa May urged to sack housing tsar Roger Scruton over 'Islamophobic and antisemitic comments' - The Independent
item.description:
Theresa May urged to sack housing tsar Roger Scruton over 'Islamophobic and antisemitic comments'  The Independent

Theresa May is facing pressure to sack her newly appointed housing tsar over claims he made Islamophobic, antisemitic and homophobic comments in a series of articles and books. Professor Sir Roger Scruton, a controversial philosopher, was chosen to advise the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government at the weekend, as chairman of a new public body to champion beautiful buildings. Labour MPs are now urging ministers to sack the conservative academic after it emerged he had described homosexuality as "not normal" and said Islamophobia was a "propaganda word". - Read more Criminal...

item.title: Emily Thornberry contradicts Jeremy Corbyn and insists Labour could still back Final Say Brexit referendum - The Independent
item.description:
Emily Thornberry contradicts Jeremy Corbyn and insists Labour could still back Final Say Brexit referendum  The Independent

Emily Thornberry has sought to calm Labour anger by saying the party could still back a Final Say Brexit referendum – just a day after Jeremy Corbyn rubbished the idea. The shadow foreign secretary said “all options remain on the table” if Labour fails to force a general election by voting against the deal Theresa May still hopes to strike within the next few days. item.title: Brexit: Jeremy Corbyn rejects calls for Final Say referendum, despite backlash from his own MPs - The Independent
item.description:
Brexit: Jeremy Corbyn rejects calls for Final Say referendum, despite backlash from his own MPs  The Independent

Jeremy Corbyn has rejected growing calls for a Final Say referendum, despite a backlash from his own MPs for saying Brexit cannot be stopped. The Labour leader faced strong criticism – including from a shadow minister – after an interview in which he insisted the process of EU withdrawal could not be halted. item.title: Teenager dies in fifth London stabbing in a week - RTÉ News
item.description:
Teenager dies in fifth London stabbing in a week  RTÉ News

A 16-year-old boy has died in the fifth suspected fatal stabbing in London in a week. The victim was found with suspected stab wounds in Tulse Hill, south London, after police were called to reports of a shooting in an estate before 11pm last night. The Metropolitan Police said it had opened a murder inquiry. The suspected murder would bring the number of homicides in London this year to 117. On Monday, the Mayor of London warned it could take a generation to turn the tide of violent crime in the city. item.title: Solving knife crime will take a decade, says mayor Sadiq Khan - The Telegraph
item.description:
Solving knife crime will take a decade, says mayor Sadiq Khan  The Telegraph

Solving knife crime will take a decade because of the way even primary school children are now carrying weapons, London’s mayor Sadiq Khan warned today. He said police across the UK were facing a surge in violent crime at the same time as they had fewer officers to combat it because of government funding cuts. The killing of a 22 year old man in London at the weekend - the fourth fatal stabbing in five days - brought this year’s murder toll in the capital alone to 118. item.description:

Five men have been arrested after a video was posted online of a burning cardboard model of Grenfell Tower, the West London apartment building where 72 people died last year. item.description:
Fury over 'gagging clause' preventing Grenfell cladding experts criticising Theresa May  The Independent

The government has been accused of “unforgivable cowardice” after it emerged experts hired to test cladding in the wake of the Grenfell Tower fire were banned from criticising Theresa May. item.description:
Grenfell tower effigy: Sixth man arrested over video showing model being burned on a bonfire  The Independent

Police have arrested a sixth man over a video showing an effigy of Grenfell Tower being burned on a bonfire. item.title: Surge in gang violence not caused by Conservative cuts to police numbers, crime minister insists - The Independent
item.description:
Surge in gang violence not caused by Conservative cuts to police numbers, crime minister insists  The Independent

The recent spike in gang-related violence in London is not due to a cut in police numbers but because of a change in the nature of crime, the crime minister has said. Victoria Atkins said that claims police numbers were responsible for the surge in crime were not supported by historical records. She also played down the argument made by National Police Chiefs' Council chairwoman Sara Thornton that political concentration on hate crimes like misogyny were distracting stretched forces' focus away from core policing priorities. item.title: Crossrail boss steps down after project delays - The Guardian
item.description:
Crossrail boss steps down after project delays  The Guardian

Crossrail’s chief executive is to step down, it has been announced, a week after the government agreed to a new cash injection to complete the delayed £15.4bn project. Simon Wright will be replaced by Mark Wild, the managing director of London Underground, who will remain in charge until the opening of the central section of Crossrail, which will be known as the Elizabeth line. The line was due to be completed in December, but Crossrail announced in August that it would take up to another year to get trains running on the underground core section. Sadiq Khan has told Michel Barnier the EU must prepare to delay Brexit given the lack of support in parliament for a deal, and growing support for a second referendum.
